description.value: Marble portrait statue of the emperor Septimius Severus in military dress. He is shown with his characteristic forked beard and tight curled hair, and is wearing military dress. The statue is not carved fully in the round, but is flat and unfinished at the back, suggesting that it was part of an architectural design.

description.value: COMPASS Title: Sandstone conglomerate statue of Khaemwaset

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Sandstone conglomerate statue of Khaemwaset: depicted wearing a short wig and kilt and standing with left foot advanced and holding two standards: the right (now damaged) was probably surmounted by a representation of the Osirian triad and is inscribed with the prenomen and epithets of Ramses II; the left is surmounted by the fetish of Abydos and inscribed with the nomen and epithets of Ramses II. The inscription around the base contains a prayer to Atum and that around the feet of the figure describes describing the setting up of this monument in Tawer, probably at Abydos. There are two vertical registers of hieroglyphs on the dorsal pillar, continued on both the right and left sides, contain a prayer to Osiris.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Black granite head; striated wig; broken-off close to the chin.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Black granite head; striated wig; broken-off close to the chin.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary black granite head of a male official, roughly broken at the chin.

He wears a striated wig set low on the forehead and tucked behind the ears. His eyebrows are slightly arched and carved in raised relief, while the eyes have a thick outline and sharply pointed cosmetic lines extending out towards the temple. The bridge of his nose is long and slim, while the nostrils are broad. His mouth is positioned close to the tip of the nose. He has full thick lips curved into a slight smile. His face is rounded and fleshy in appearance, particularly at the jawline.

The ends of the wig are damaged, and there are numerous small chips across the face and wig. The figure is attached to a thick modern base.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone fragment of a scribal figure, only the right side of the upper body remaining.

The chest appears bare, with subtle indication of the musculature and a partial outline of the right side waist. On the breast and upper arm are two incised depictions of deities; the figure on the chest is an unidentified male, while the other can be identified as the god Min based on the crown, flail, and his erect phallus. Both figures have traces of a blue-green colour. On the reverse is a thick band of clothing reaching from the left side of the neck and wrapping around the right side of the body. At his back in carved relief is a long tube for the scribal reed brushes, part of the hieroglyph sign depicting the scribal kit.

The head, right forearm, and left side of the figure are missing.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: COMPASS Title: Granodiorite statue of Senwosret I

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Head and torso of granodiorite statue of Senusret I; prenomen inscribed on belt.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Head and torso of granodiorite statue of Senusret I: depicting Senusret I striding bare-chested and wearing a royal headcloth and a kilt with narrow pleats. Enclosed in a cartouche and carved in large hieroglyphs, the king's prenomen decorates the centre of the wide belt holding his kilt in place. The thick body of the royal uraeus cobra, its hood now broken away, completes five turns as it winds over the top of the king's pleated headcloth. The wide back pillar covers the back of the headcloth and narrows at the top in the form of an obelisk. Due to damage, the form of the mouth can only be conjectured. A naturalistic mouth would complete the image aesthetically. However, the extremely wide rounded corners preserved at the sides of the mouth and the full shape of the lower lip suggest that the king's mouth was highly stylized with almost everted lips, significantly altering the apparent naturalism of his expression.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Head and torso of granodiorite statue of Senusret I: depicting Senusret I striding bare-chested and wearing a royal headcloth and a kilt with narrow pleats. Enclosed in a cartouche and carved in large hieroglyphs, the king's prenomen decorates the centre of the wide belt holding his kilt in place. The thick body of the royal uraeus cobra, its hood now broken away, completes five turns as it winds over the top of the king's pleated headcloth. The wide back pillar covers the back of the headcloth and narrows at the top in the form of an obelisk. Due to damage, the form of the mouth can only be conjectured. A naturalistic mouth would complete the image aesthetically. However, the extremely wide rounded corners preserved at the sides of the mouth and the full shape of the lower lip suggest that the king's mouth was highly stylized with almost everted lips, significantly altering the apparent naturalism of his expression.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Sandstone statue of Nefertiti:  this headless and footless figure of Nefertiti depicts her standing, wearing a full-length diaphanous pleated gown coloured white, with one sleeve fashionably shorter than the other. The ends of her sash fall down the front of each leg as far as the shin. On the left side of the figure the plain edge of her garment runs from elbow to ankle. Traces of red and blue indicate the figure was wearing a bead collar; the flesh is coloured red. Although one forearm and both hands are lost, it is clear the queen once held something before her. It was not an altar, however, which would have been supported from beneath; whatever it was, she held it by the sides. The head, back of the neck and top of the back pillar were originally made from a separate piece of sandstone, but the head must have been replaced at least once, since the site of the break has been smoothed over and covered with plaster. The inscription on the back pillar gives the titles and name of Nefertiti and the later form of the Aten's name, which does not occur before year 9. The queen's physique, too - although she has prominent breasts, a well-rounded stomach, large buttocks, and over-developed thighs - exhibits the less exaggerated style of the later years of the reign. The figure, which has been reassembled from several fragments, is severely mutilated throughout. The face, fore-arms and feet are missing, and of the offering-table only the portion nearest the body remains. Much of the original paint is still visible.

description.value: Granite head and upper torso of a King: the king represented here, wearing the royal nemes headcloth with a uraeus at the forehead, is anonymous. Features from the aging faces on some statues of Amenemhat III have been recognizably reproduced - specifically the widely spaced, horizontally set, heavily pouched eyes, and the unsmiling mouth. However, here, the eyes are narrower; the mouth is smaller and more indeterminate in shape; the chin is less prominent. Overall, the facial modeling is much less plastic, and the sober expression lacks the brooding, almost brutal quality of the Amenemhat III prototypes. The face is quite long.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary granite upper body of a king, the lower body now missing.

He wears the nemes headcloth with the material tucked behind his ears, and the long striped lappets extending down onto his chest. Above his forehead is the uraeus cobra, now headless, with its coiled body extending over the top of the headcloth. His eyes are wide-set, slanted and narrow, with visibly sunken skin underneath. His eyebrows are conveyed as a slightly arched ridge. His nose has been broken off with an implement that has left behind a rectangular recess in the stone. His mouth is small with a slightly fleshier lower lip, and the outer corners are downturned creating a stern expression. His face is long in appearance, while his jawline is rounded and fleshy. A thick raised line around his neck possibly indicates a necklace. His chest is bare, with notable ridges at the breastbone area.
The statue is damaged in several areas including the top and outer edges of the nemes headcloth on both si… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: COMPASS Title: Unfinished basalt statue of a queen or goddess

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Unfinished basalt statue of a seated female figure.   A basalt stone block has been roughed out through careful chiselling to provide the outline of a female figure seated upon a low backed chair or throne, with her hands clearly placed on the upper legs and the head adorned with a headdress or crown. The shape of stone at the forehead would also suggest that this would, once completed, have formed a uraeus. Both the crown and use of the uraeus suggest that this piece was likely intended to represent a royal or divine female figure once finished.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: COMPASS Title: Quartzite statue of Peraha

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Red quartzite kneeling naophorous statue of Paaha shown cupping left hand to the mouth; representation of Ptah within the shrine held by the right hand; incised Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar and round the plinth.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Red quartzite mendicant statue of Paaha: The god Ptah - or more specifically, a cult statue of the god - is represented standing in a small naos, or shrine. Paaha is represented sitting cross-legged on the ground with his legs and feet covered by his long kilt. As was often the case with kneeling statues holding cult images, Ptah's shrine is balanced on one thigh, the proper left, and held by Paaha's corresponding left hand. Here, the sculptor has blundered by making the shrine so high that it impinges on his chin. The reason for doing this, apparently, was to support Paaha's raised hand. The gesture, hand to mouth with palm upward and thumb awkwardly forward, was one of begging offerings from the god. There is incised hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar and round the plinth.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: COMPASS Title: Quartzite statue of Amenwahsu

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Red quartzite kneeling stelophorous statue of Amenwahsu; stela depicts solar barque above five rows of Hieroglyphic text; text also on back-pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Red quartzite stelophorous statue of Amenwahsu: Amenwahsu kneels with hands raised, palms up, in the attitude of worship. His hands are supported by a stela bearing a prayer to the sun-god Ra-Horakhty. The same deity, now combined with the great state god Amun, is depicted in the lunette at the top as a man with a ram's head, crossing heaven in a barque.  The stela-shaped back pillar of the statue is inscribed in mirror image with two offering formulae, one addressed to the composite sun-god Ra-Horakhty-Atum, and the other to Osiris, god of the dead. Considering the hardness of the stone, the carving is particularly fine.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

The stela-shaped back pillar of the statue is inscribed in mirror image with two offering formulae, one addressed to the composite sun-god Ra-Horakhty-Atum, and the other to Osiris, god of the dead. Considering the hardness of the stone, the carving is particularly fine.

description.value: Head and right side of the body of a basalt male figure: wearing a bag-wig and a pectoral depicting the goddess Neith and Psamtek II, named by the cartouches. The original pectoral, presumably naming an earlier pharaoh, has been erased. The nomen of Psamtek II is also on the right shoulder, and there are three columns of Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar.

description.value: Fragmentary basalt figure of an elite official, the lower body and base now missing.   The figure wears a smooth shoulder-length ‘bag wig’, a simple headcloth style associated with the 26th Dynasty, and the surviving left side of the body indicates that the figure also wore a kilt belted at the waist. Though the right portion of the upper body and the lower body are lost, the position of the left arm is slightly outstretched at the bend of the elbow which suggests that the figure may have once held an object such as a naos shrine or divine image. The bent elbow also indicates that the statue could originally have been shown seated or kneeling. The cartouche of the 26th Dynasty pharaoh Psamtek II is carved into the upper part of the left arm., and around the neck is a reworked pectoral with figures carved in sunk relief of the goddess Neith and the king with another inscribed cartouche labelling the king. The statue’s eyes are wide and almond shaped, with clear incised ridges depicting … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone seated statue of Meri: this statue shows Meri with short, cropped hair and a simple pleated kilt, resting his open left hand and his fisted right hand on his thighs. The cropped hair on this statue is often found on representations of middle-aged men. But there are no other signs of age: the pleated kilt is appropriate to a young man, and the position of the hands is found on representations of both young and older men. There is hieroglyphic text at the front of the plinth.

description.value: Granodiorite statue in the form of Mutemwia, wife of Thutmose IV and mother of Amenhotep III, in the guise of the goddess Mut, protected by the wings of a vulture and enthroned upon a sacred boat, the upper-body is broken away, the hands were placed on the thighs and the right holds an ankh, part of the head of the figure is also preserved (see EA 43A), the prow is elaborated with Hathor-heads and the base of a sistrum, the stern is wanting; hieroglyphs, at the feet of the figure, give the name and titles of the queen and each side of the boat is incised with a wedjat-eye and an elongated-cartouche also giving the name and titles of the queen, the prow is inscribed with cartouches containing the prenomen and nomen of Amenhotep III. Part of the face and modius from a granodiorite sculpture of Queen Mutemwia enthroned aboard a barque.

description.value: Marble portrait head of a Roman man: this head, broken through the neck, was originally pieced across the crown. At each side are cuttings where the ears should be; while the proper right cutting is approximately ear-shaped, the left is more geometric. This feature and the presence of a slight ridge above the brow, with no trace of hair, suggest that the subject might have worn a helmet. The subject is a man of mature years, with furrowed brow and carefully modelled winged eyebrows. Beneath these, the fleshy sockets and upper brows are prominent. The tear-ducts are hardly apparent and the lower lids lost in a bag of flesh. The nose is clearly aquiline; the mouth, with thin upper lip, downturned. Unexpectedly, there are no deep nasolabial lines. The chin is very prominent, the jowls fleshy but unlined. The subject has been identified as Mark Antony.

description.value: Granodiorite statue of Amenhotep III: the statue, mounted on a pedestal, represents a figure seated on a throne, wearing the 'nemes' head-dress with uraeus, and a beard, bead-collar, short skirt and tail. On the sides of the throne is incised a hieroglyphic symbol flanked by lily and papyrus flowers intertwined, symbolising the union of the Two Lands. The inscriptions are incised on the girdle of the skirt and on the front and back of the throne. The inscriptions are well preserved, with the exception of the one on the right-hand side of the front of the throne, which is somewhat mutilated. The cartouches containing the name of Amenhotep III and the other places in which this name appears have been erased and recut in antiquity. The statue has been restored.

description.value: Granodiorite statue of Amenhotep III: the statue, mounted on a pedestal, represents a figure seated on a throne, wearing the 'nemes' head-dress with uraeus, and a beard, bead-collar, short skirt and tail. On the sides of the throne is incised a hieroglyphic symbol flanked by lily and papyrus flowers intertwined, symbolising the union of the Two Lands. The inscriptions are incised on the girdle of the skirt and on the front and back of the throne. The inscriptions are well preserved, with the exception of the one on the right-hand side of the front of the throne, which is somewhat mutilated. The cartouches containing the name of Amenhotep III and the other places in which this name appears have been erased and recut in antiquity. The statue has been restored.

description.value: Marble head from a statue of Octavian in the style of a Hellenistic prince.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Marble head from a statue of Octavian: in the style of a Hellenistic prince. The lower edge of the neck, fashioned as a tenon to fit into a draped torso (the join then concealed by drapery), is lost. The proper left ear is chipped. The surface is damaged

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Marble head from a statue of Octavian: in the style of a Hellenistic prince. The lower edge of the neck, fashioned as a tenon to fit into a draped torso (the join then concealed by drapery), is lost. The proper left ear is chipped. The surface is damaged at the outer end of the proper left eyebrow, to the left of the mouth, and at the left edge of the neck. The nose has been replaced, the glued join concealed. The restoration necessitated some superficial reworking of the lips and chin. In general the head, which is carved in Carrara marble with some mineral inclusions, has the appearance of an ancient piece cleaned and reworked for the antiquities market.
Octavian appears pensive, his abundant thick locks of hair kept well clear of the high brow and broad face.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone block-statue of Iti; thirteen rows of Hieroglyphic text including the prenomen of Shabako.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone block-statue of Iti: the inscription on the front dates it to the fifteenth regnal year of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty king Shabako. Iti's statue is carved in white limestone, and the only remaining color is black on the wig. The figure is fully cloaked, with only the head and hands exposed. Iti's head is slightly raised. His left hand lies flat on his right upper arm, while the right holds a stalk of cos lettuce. The sides of the rather tall base were never finished, presumably because the statue was to be placed in a separate outer base. There are a number of features that betray the archaizing nature of this work. The forms of the body - the overhang of the arms, the outside contours of the legs, even the waistline visible at the back - are so clearly delineated as to suggest a pseudo-block statue, rather than a fully cloaked block statue. The upper layer of the double wig, a wig long out of use, looks less like hair than some kind of headcloth.The tilt of the head could have come from an earlier model, but it has led the sculptor to tip the chin beard as well, leaving an awkward gap. The sculptor seems also to have assumed that chin beards, out of fashion in his day, were artificial attachments like the beards worn by kings and gods, and so he has carved a strap on each side of the jaw, to connect it with Iti's wig. Iti has long, narrow almond eyes and distinctively shaped brows; there is emphasis on the nostrils, with its small folds of flesh to the sides; and he has a crisply outlined, pleasantly set mouth.

description.value:
Limestone block statue of Turi.

His arms are crossed with his left hand placed flat against the top of the block form and his right hand holding an item that is now partially damaged. There are traces of red paint across his hands denoting his skin. His body is fully enveloped, and there is a slight bulging at both sides to indicate his upper arms but minimal further indications of his limbs. At the front of the block form are three columns of incised text. Each column includes a slim border that is left open at the top and bottom, and the final line of inscription extends out longer towards his feet. Across his feet is a separate small horizontal line of inscription. Across the top of the base is another horizontal line, now badly damaged and many of the signs obscured.

The top of the block form is heavily damaged with uneven breaks at the neck and wig. A separate break may indicate that Turi was depicted with a short formal beard. The statue has several gouges to th… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Green schist statue of Mentuhotep VI:  the statuette is a very respectable piece of work. Mentuhotep stands in the traditional pose with left leg advanced, his limbs connected to a back pillar by negative space. He wears a nemes with uraeus, and a 'shendyt' kilt. His hands, at his sides, hold two different objects. The nature of the one in his proper left hand is unclear (some sort of case?); but that in the right is a folded cloth, with its ends hanging down behind.  The well-proportioned body is simply but effectively modeled with the suggestion of muscles in arms and legs and just the hint of a paunch. There are some nicely observed details, such as the slight flare of the kilt pleats over the buttocks. But there also seems to be uncertainty in the way that the forehead band of the nemes, a single strip, has been carved twice over the front and left side of the face, and the way the band descends into very indeterminate shapes in front of the ears. There is an inept carving of the inscription on the back pillar. The nemes has a shape characteristic of the late Middle Kingdom, rising steeply over the top of the head but rather meager in front view, with small, slanted lappets. The face, too, has a meager quality, due partly to the lack of modeling, but also to the small, short chin. Though the mouth is small in proportion to the nose and eyes, it seems to fill the bottom of the face. The mouth is horizontally set and the eyes rather heavy lidded, features that are found in other royal heads of approximately the same date.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Green schist statue of Mentuhotep VI:  the statuette is a very respectable piece of work. Mentuhotep stands in the traditional pose with left leg advanced, his limbs connected to a back pillar by negative space. He wears a nemes with uraeus, and a 'shendy

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Green schist statue of Mentuhotep VI:  the statuette is a very respectable piece of work. Mentuhotep stands in the traditional pose with left leg advanced, his limbs connected to a back pillar by negative space. He wears a nemes with uraeus, and a 'shendyt' kilt. His hands, at his sides, hold two different objects. The nature of the one in his proper left hand is unclear (some sort of case?); but that in the right is a folded cloth, with its ends hanging down behind.  The well-proportioned body is simply but effectively modeled with the suggestion of muscles in arms and legs and just the hint of a paunch. There are some nicely observed details, such as the slight flare of the kilt pleats over the buttocks. But there also seems to be uncertainty in the way that the forehead band of the nemes, a single strip, has been carved twice over the front and left side of the face, and the way the band descends into very indeterminate shapes in front of the ears. There is an inept carving of the inscription on the back pillar. The nemes has a shape characteristic of the late Middle Kingdom, rising steeply over the top of the head but rather meager in front view, with small, slanted lappets. The face, too, has a meager quality, due partly to the lack of modeling, but also to the small, short chin. Though the mouth is small in proportion to the nose and eyes, it seems to fill the bottom of the face. The mouth is horizontally set and the eyes rather heavy lidded, features that are found in other royal heads of approximately the same date.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary green schist figure of king Mentuhotep VI, the lower legs and base now missing.

The king wears the nemes headcloth, with wide striped lappets that extend over the shoulders and a twisted braid at the back. The material is tucked behind the ears, and a faint horizontal band across the forehead. Above this is the coiled body of the uraeus cobra, its head now lost. His eyes are narrow and slanted. The nose is almost as broad as the mouth, which features thin lips and is sharply incised around the lower lip. His face is particularly rounded at the jawline, with a clear bulge of flesh around the neck. His upper body is bare, and has a subtly modelled torso and chest. Both broad arms are held at either side of the body, with an uncertain object held in the left hand and a piece of folded cloth held in the right hand. He wears a belted shendyt kilt, and his left leg clearly strides out in advance of the right leg. On the reverse is a slim back-pillar with a single column … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Quartzite statue of Nakhtherheb: Nakhtherheb is shown kneeling  in reverence before Osiris, from whom he seeks benefits, his head slightly raised and his hands lying flat on his thighs. His unadorned headdress and short, plain kilt enhance the viewer's impression of deliberate simplicity and a kind of monumental tranquility. In Nakhtherheb's face and body, however, there is a considerable amount of modeled detail. His almond-shaped eyes and the high-set, horizontal line of his eyebrows, as well as the sickle-shaped curve of his slight smile, follow the pattern for facial features set early in the Twenty-sixth Dynasty. But this face is broad and full, consonant with the body, which, though not fat, looks soft and fleshy. Nakhtherheb's torso is designed as three sets of swelling curves placed one below the other and comprising the breast, the rib cage, and the abdomen. The large round navel is set within a bulge shaped rather like a teardrop. The plinth is inscribed with a horizontal register of hieroglyphs and the dorsal pillar with two vertical registers of hieroglyphs.

description.value: COMPASS Title: Quartzite block statue of Senmut

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Quartzite block-statue of Senenmut: the text that covers his cloaked form and continues on the base contains the traditional offering formula and a long  compendium of titles and laudatory epithets. It is clear that an unusual amount of care went into the composition of the inscription, with its wide prosopographical repertoire, and into its arrangement on the statue surface. The text on the body stresses Senenmut's relationship with Thutmose III. Even in the lines that refer to his role as tutor of the Princess Neferura she is identified as the daughter of Thutmose II, not of Hatshepsut. The inscriptions on the base, however, tell a different story. Here Hatshepsut dominates. Senenmut's body contours are slightly indicated, the elbows protrude from the matrix, and the forearms and hands are indicated in very low relief on the top of the cube. He wears a shoulder-length wig with undulating striations. His short beard, of the kind typically worn by officials, is punctuated by a series of horizontal divisions. The forehead is quite low, and the high arched brows are close to the wig band. The eyes are well rounded and slightly bulging. The ears are quite large for an early Eighteenth Dynasty example, again reflecting Middle Kingdom influence. Although the face is damaged, we can discern that the nose was narrow but broad at the tip and the lips were straight and fairly thick. Both were shaved down after they were broken, possibly in preparation for a restoration that was never realized. In its current damaged state the face has a distinctly brutish aspect that is at variance with the fine quality of its material and execution.

description.value:
Headless granodiorite block statue of a male official named Tjauwy.

His hands are crossed over the top of the block form, and in his right hand he holds the counterweight for a thick menat necklace which drapes down onto the front of the block. Beside the necklace is a large Hathor cow-head in raised relief. The goddess is shown wearing the sun-disc crown topped with two ostrich feathers. The cow’s head is framed by two short columns of incised text with a thin border at the bottom, followed by three separate rows of text that are inscribed across Tjauwy’s feet. Both the left and right side of his block form are inscribed with eight rows of text, the final line extending onto the top of the statue base. On the reverse is a broad back-pillar that is also inscribed with four columns of text, reading from right to left. At the concluding signs of the final line on the left there is a brief additional row of text inscribed across the statue base. A further line of continuous text … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fragment of a black granite statue bearing the incised cartouches of Sobekhotep I and epithets.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragment of a black granite statue base with cartouches and epithets of king Sobekhotep I.
The fragment appears to be the right-side corner of a statue base, with two clear columns of incised inscription defined by a slim border. The top of the inscription and the remaining text is now missing, and much of the rest of the fragment is damaged. Traces of a third line on the left side of the fragment are difficult to read given the damage to this area, which appears to have been deliberately erased through chiselling of the stone.

description.value: COMPASS Title: Wooden statue from the tomb of Ramesses I

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Wooden figure of a man, probably Ramses I, standing with left foot advanced, wearing bag-wig and kilt, the eyes and eyebrows were originally inlaid, the arms are missing (although one tenon, now detached, does survive), the figure probably held a mace in the right and a stave in the left hand, one leg and both feet are restored, the whole bears traces of a layer of bitumen.

description.value: Scribal statue of Pesshuper: a red quartzite statue of the Theban high official Pesshuper as a scribe. Hieroglyphic texts are incised on the plinth, on the papyrus roll on Pesshuper's lap, and on the back pillar of the statue. Pesshuper's left arm, which holds the roll, is damaged. On his knee is a shell-shaped container with inkwells, and over his left shoulder is slung the hieroglyph representing scribal equipment. On the roll the traditional funerary invocation is inscribed in vertical lines so as to be read by the statue, not the spectator. On the right arm is written the cartouche of his patroness. Further funerary invocations are written on his kilt in eight vertical lines and around the plinth, in a single horizontal line. Three more vertical lines (right to left) are inscribed on the back pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary head of a limestone male statue.

The figure wears a striated wig tucked behind the oversized ears. The edges of the wig are now damaged, but at full length they likely reached to his shoulders. His eyes are narrow with faintly modelled eyebrows, and the surviving outline of the nose shows that it was broad in shape. The corners of the mouth appear slightly upturned suggesting a faint smile, while the rest of the lips, chin, and nose are now defaced. The face is fleshy in appearance, with further damage to the cheeks and around the brow.

The object is now attached to a modern rectangular base.

description.value:
Stela and part of the lower legs of a limestone stelophorous statue of Ramose.

The stela was originally held by a kneeling figure of a male official whose hands perhaps rested on the top of the stela. It consists of a lunette with a shen ring and set of wedjat eyes, followed by five rows of incised text. Directly underneath this are a further two lines of inscription inscribed across the legs of the figure. The left leg is damaged, and some of the signs from the final line of text are now obscured.

The stela has been broken off from the figure in antiquity and is now supported on a slim modern mount. The top edges of the stela have several large chips.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Stela and part of the lower legs of a limestone stelophorous statue of Ramose.

The stela was originally held by a kneeling figure of a male official whose hands perhaps rested on the top of the stela. It consists of a lunette with a shen ring and set of wedjat eyes, followed by five rows of incised text. Directly underneath this are a further two lines of inscription inscribed across the legs of the figure. The left leg is damaged, and some of the signs from the final line of text are now obscured.

The stela has been broken off from the figure in antiquity and is now supported on a slim modern mount. The top edges of the stela have several large chips.

description.value: Red granite statue of lion of Amenhotep III: this lion is depicted in a recumbent pose, forming a mirror image to its companion piece. It lies on its side: the forepaws crossed, the farther of the hind paws emerging from under the nearer one, the tail curling forward around the rump and resting on the base. The sculpture combines marvelously the stylized mane and hair with a naturalistic treatment of the body. The muzzle projects realistically, with solid jawbones and raised veins. A stylized circular mane frames the head, and the fur is rendered by a raised surface on the chest, the shoulders, and the back. The eyes are hollowed and were probably inlaid. The whiskers are incised on the muzzle; small, round protuberances in the ear suggest the tufts of hair. The naturalistic treatment of the physiognomy is enhanced by anatomical details - for example, the twisted hind paws, of which the farther one is turned upward. On the external side of the paws, the folds are marked by deep furrows. The rump is treated with a bold modeling of musculature; and parallel depressions alternate with raised ribs on the flank. The lion was later reinscribed several times. First a four-column text was engraved on the breast, identifying the monument as "The good god, lion of rulers, wild when he sees his enemies treading his path, [it is the king] ... divine ruler of Thebes, who brought it." The royal cartouche, in which only the last signs are preserved, could belong to Akhenaten. Shortly afterward, a text of Tutankhamun's was inscribed on the base, stating that the king renewed this monument for Amenhotep III. Ultimately, during the reuse of these lions in Gebel Barkal, the two cartouches of the Kushite ruler Amanislo were added on both lions.These cartouches occupy the left forepaw, because of the anterior four-column inscription. It was probably also at that time that the names of Tutankhamun in the third and fourth cartouches on the base were erased (with the exception of "Amun" and a remnant of "ankh") to be replaced by those of Amanislo, on a plaster patch that is now lost, leaving the original particle of Amun, common to both names.

description.value: Scribe statue of Nikheftek

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone statue of the male official Nikheftek on a slim rectangular base, the head and part of the left side of the body now lost.

His upper body is bare, with traces of red-brown paint used to indicate the skin. His waist is narrowed and the musculature of his chest and abdomen is clearly conveyed. Black paint has been used across the negative space between his arms and torso. His hands rest on his knees, with the left hand now damaged. In his right hand he holds an unrolled section of papyrus, with a section of the material stretched out across his lap. A partial horizontal line of incised text survives across this area, and is oriented towards the statue. He wears a short kilt reaching to his knees, with clear traces of white paint. He is shown in a cross-legged position, with his feet tucked underneath the legs.

There is damage to the right shoulder, which has been repaired in modern times. Two drilled holes are also visible across this area. A thin… (See Merlin record for full description)

His upper body is bare, with traces of red-brown paint used to indicate the skin. His waist is narrowed and the musculature of his chest and abdomen is clearly conveyed. Black paint has been used across the negative space between his arms and torso. His hands rest on his knees, with the left hand now damaged. In his right hand he holds an unrolled section of papyrus, with a section of the material stretched out across his lap. A partial horizontal line of incised text survives across this area, and is oriented towards the statue. He wears a short kilt reaching to his knees, with clear traces of white paint. He is shown in a cross-legged position, with his feet tucked underneath the legs.

There is damage to the right shoulder, which has been repaired in modern times. Two drilled holes are also visible across this area. A thin… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Lower portion of a limestone squatting statue.

The upper body is now lost, but he wears a short kilt belted at the waist. The fringed detail of the belt is still visible across the back of the figure. Across the top of his clothing at least ten horizontal lines of text have been inscribed, though the outer edges of each line are now obscured. The figure likely held his arms by his sides with the hands at his lap, however the stone has been heavily damaged on either side of his clothing. His right knee is visible and is laid flat, showing that he originally sat cross-legged. At his lower right leg is further fringed detail of his clothing. Across the right side of his clothing are a further seven horizontal lines of incised text, undefined by a border and reading from right to left. The left side of his body clearly also had a similar layout of inscription, though only the upper portion of five lines of incised text nor remains. On the reverse next to these remaining signs is a… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone statue of a male and female figure, the male head now lost and with damage to the lower legs of both figures.

The male has a bare upper body, with the musculature of the abdomen subtly modelled. His arms are held by the sides, with the left hand now lost. He wears a shendyt kilt with a thick belt, with damage to the left side edge of the clothing along the thigh. The female wears a large smooth wig, possibly a Hathor-wig though the typically curled ends are now missing. Her wig is tucked behind the ears, and her facial features are now obscured. She wears a tight-fitting sheath dress with straps of the material across the chest meeting at the breastbone. Her waist is narrowed and there is a suggestion of the curvature of her hips and legs underneath the clothing. Her arms are also held by her sides with her palms placed flat against her thighs. On the reverse of the broad back-plinth are 8 partial columns of incised text, which is separated into four colu… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone standing figure of Tjaiasetimu: in archaising dress, based on the conventional standing mortuary figures of the Old Kingdom, wearing short wig and kilt; the waist-band of the kilt, the base and the dorsal pillar are inscribed with hieroglyphs.

description.value: Mid-riff and leg section of a limestone figure of Wennefer, High-Priest of Thoth carrying a tray upon which sits a baboon; three columns of Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Mid-riff and leg section of a limestone figure of Wennefer, High-Priest of Thoth carrying a tray upon which sits a baboon; three columns of Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone theophorous figure of Wennefer, the upper body and legs of the statue now lost.   He wears a long garment with a strap of material visible on the lower right side, which may indicate that his clothing was in the style of the so-called ‘Persian wrap’ and thus would originally have included a knot of material tied across the chest to secure it in place. In either hand he holds out a square-shaped stand upon which sits a fragmentary squatting baboon, which likely represents the male god Thoth. The baboon’s hind legs are flat against the stand and the tail is curled around to its right side, while the upper body and head are now broken off. On the reverse is the mid-section of a broad back-pillar with three columns of inscribed text left undefined by border lines, and with the beginning and conclusion of each line now lost.  Across the stone surface there are numerous chips at the male figure’s hands, skirt, and edges of the stand. An extended part of the lower back pillar has su… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Dark hardstone seated figure wearing a diadem; possibly a fake.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Seated male figure of dark hardstone, possibly granodiorite, on a slim rectangular base.  The figure is shown seated on a high backed chair, and wears a shoulder-length striated wig with a raised diadem. The wig is set high on the forehead and tucked behind the large ears. His eyes are almond shaped with a heavy upper eyelid, with a broad nose and mouth. His neck is also broad, and the head is clearly raised to indicate the upward gaze of the figure. His upper body is bare and both arms are held at the side of the body with the palms placed flat against the knees. His limbs are extremely broad and oversized, while this chest and waist are crudely modelled. He appears to wear a short kilt though there is no clear delineation of the clothing edges at the waist or legs. On the reverse the top of the seat reaches to the edge of the figure’s wig, and the seat is uninscribed.  The statue appears to be in good condition with minimal damage. The object has been attached to a modern rectangular… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fragmentary calcite group statue, only two pairs of feet and a partial section of the statue base remaining.  The group statue is broken off from the ankle of both figures, with fragments of stone behind the limbs also still intact. Both sets of feet are in close proximity to one another. There are no clear traces of clothing visible at the break of the ankles.   There are small chips across the surface of both sets of feet, and the darkened surface of the stone suggests that the figure was subjected to an intense heat after its construction. The base has been reconstructed in modern times.

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone figure of an official, only the right-side portion of the body and base now intact.

The figure’s right leg is cloaked and laid flat, suggesting that he adopted a cross-legged position. Much of the body is now lost. Two lines of continuous text are inscribed around the statue base, both beginning at the front of the base. These are two offering formulae based on their opening lines, and on the right side this continues with a dedication to Hathor, Mistress of Thebes.

The left side of the figure and base has been broken off, and both right corners of the statue base are also damaged. The object is now supported on a thick modern base.

description.value:
Fragmentary grey stone figure of the god Min, the feet now missing.

He wears a fragmentary crown adorned with a headband tied at the back of the head, and a slot at the top of the crown which would have been used to insert an upper section, likely the double plume headdress. A uraeus cobra sits above Min’s forehead. His soft facial features include slightly hooded eyes, a broad nose and a small mouth with a particularly fleshy appearance of the face around the mouth and chin. A small false beard extends from his chin, part of the right corner now missing. He wears a detailed broad-collar and pectoral around his neck, the latter of which has broad straps that hang over the upper body, and inside depicts a winged sun-disc. These straps are also visible on the back, and possibly extended into a cape. The god is depicted nude, and on both upper arms he also wears a detailed cuff and at his wrists an identical bracelet. His left hand held his erect phallus, now missing, while his r… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Fragmentary grey stone figure of the god Min, the feet now missing.

He wears a fragmentary crown adorned with a headband tied at the back of the head, and a slot at the top of the crown which would have been used to insert an upper section, likely the double plume headdress. A uraeus cobra sits above Min’s forehead. His soft facial features include slightly hooded eyes, a broad nose and a small mouth with a particularly fleshy appearance of the face around the mouth and chin. A small false beard extends from his chin, part of the right corner now missing. He wears a detailed broad-collar and pectoral around his neck, the latter of which has broad straps that hang over the upper body, and inside depicts a winged sun-disc. These straps are also visible on the back, and possibly extended into a cape. The god is depicted nude, and on both upper arms he also wears a detailed cuff and at his wrists an identical bracelet. His left hand held his erect phallus, now missing, while his r… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Head and upper body of pink/grey granite monumental statue of Ramses II (one of a pair placed before the door of the Ramesseum) wearing nemes head-cloth and circlet of uraei (about half now lost), the sculptor has exploited the bichrome nature of the stone to emphasise the division between body and face; the dorsal pillar is inscribed with vertical registers of hieroglyphs - giving the name and titles of the king and part of a dedication to Amun-Ra; in 1817 it was noted that there were traces of colour upon the statue and it may have, therefore, been painted red in antiquity.

description.value: Bronze head from an over-life-sized statue of Augustus: the head is broken through the neck but is otherwise in an excellent state of preservation.  There are four fragments of plaster from the head. The eyes are inlaid, with glass pupils set in metal rings, the irises of calcite. The eyebrows are plastically rendered. The emperor's head is turned to his right, with the pronounced twist to the neck typical of Hellenistic work. The hair falls on the brow in the divided and curving cut that marked most of Augustus's portraits as emperor.  The facial planes are broad. The mouth is slightly downturned, a feature of late Hellenistic portraiture. The ears project markedly, the upper lobes bending forwards.

legal.credit_line: RESTRICTED

The emperor's head is turned to his right, with the pronounced twist to the neck typical of Hellenistic work. The hair falls on the brow in the divided and curving cut that marked most of Augustus's portraits as emperor.  The facial planes are broad. The mouth is slightly downturned, a feature of late Hellenistic portraiture. The ears project markedly, the upper lobes bending forwards.

description.value: Basalt standing statue of the priest Pasherbastet: the way in which the head is cocked to one side, the treatment of the heavily lidded eyes with incised iris, and the rather tragic expression are noteworthy. The downturned mouth and the sharp line below the lower lip are characteristic of late first-century-BC royal portraits. The man wears a costume comprising a short-sleeved round-necked shirt, a wraparound skirt and a fringed shawl, whose mid-section he grasps in his left hand; the object in his right fist has been identified as a folded cloth, a symbol of aristocracy since early dynastic times. The figure strides on the left foot with one hand clenched, the artistic convention since the beginning of the dynastic period for representing male dynamism and capability for action. As a priest, the owner has a shaven head. The back pillar, which is rounded at the top and reaches the back of the head, supports the figure and was an architecturally necessary support for standing statuary but with inherent symbolism. It is incised with a column of hieroglyphs providing the name, titles and filiation of the owner.

The downturned mouth and the sharp line below the lower lip are characteristic of late first-century-BC royal portraits. The man wears a costume comprising a short-sleeved round-necked shirt, a wraparound skirt and a fringed shawl, whose mid-section he grasps in his left hand; the object in his right fist has been identified as a folded cloth, a symbol of aristocracy since early dynastic times. The figure strides on the left foot with one hand clenched, the artistic convention since the beginning of the dynastic period for representing male dynamism and capability for action. As a priest, the owner has a shaven head. The back pillar, which is rounded at the top and reaches the back of the head, supports the figure and was an architecturally necessary support for standing statuary … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Painted limestone figure of Thoth as a baboon.

The fur around his head is wife and his eyes are large with a slim nose and long snout. The head is painted with a red-brown colour, with traces of a blue-green colour along the neck area. The feathered hood or layers of fur across the chest appear as a smooth layer extending across the back and over the upper body. His paws rest on his knees. Between his hind legs his genitalia is exposed, and on his left side his tail is curled across the top of the base. This lower portion of his body is again painted with a red-brown colour, while the top of the base has been painted white.

There are minimal scratches or abrasions to the stone surface.

description.value: Lower part of a green basalt kneeling naophorous statue of the great steward Peftuaneith; Osiris within the shrine; three columns of incised Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar; six columns at the front of the shrine that include the cartouches of Apries; two rows round the plinth; head and upper body lost.

description.value:
Fragmentary red breccia male figure, only the right side of the head and shoulder remaining.

He wears a smooth shoulder-length wig with a deep outline at the forehead and faint edges around the right side of the face. The ends of the wig appear to blend into the upper body. The left side of his face is badly damaged, however his physical features are well preserved on the right side. His right eye is narrow and heavily hooded, with a arched and raised edge indicating his eyebrow. The outline of his nose appears broad in shape, and his lips are full with sharply incised edges. His chin droops slightly.

Much of the statue body is now lost, and the left side of the face and wig are particularly damaged. The fragment is now supported by a modern mount.

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone sculpture bearing the cartouches of the Aten, part of a stela once held by a figure.

The obverse is inscribed with the cartouches of the Aten in sunken relief, which have been executed to a high quality. The majority of the first cartouche on the right side survives, while only the initial signs of the second cartouche are intact. On the right side is additional incised text again of very high quality, which includes the titles and part of a cartouche for the king or queen and at the top the edge of a patterned border. There are traces of a second line with only some of the hieroglyph signs intact. There are traces of a darker colour in some of these incised signs. The left side and reverse are roughly broken, while the top of the fragment is round-topped above each of the cartouches.

There is slight damage to the signs within the first cartouche and around the top of the curved area on the right side, as well as the corner of the right side. Th… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Mudstone head and upper body of a female figure: with a broad, mask-like face and mannered features She wears the traditional sheath with two straps over the breasts and an equally traditional collar necklace. Since she does not have a uraeus, a vulture cap, or other signs of royalty, she is probably not a queen. The form of the woman's wig, with its flat-bottomed front lappets and simple vertical striations, strongly suggests that she is a goddess. The fact that she wore, on this wig, some kind of crown or headdress, now broken off, makes it even more likely that she was divine. One small detail of her costume, however, remains enigmatic: the narrow ribbon tied around her wig, with its hanging ends represented in relief on the sides of the back pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Fragmentary mudstone head and upper body of a female figure, the lower body and base now missing.   The figure wears a long, striated wig that is tucked behind her ears and sits low on the forehead. The wig also features flat-bottomed front lappets and a horizontal band across the top of the head representing a narrow ribbon, perhaps to hold the hair in place, with the ends of the ribbon depicted in relief on either side of the back-pillar on the reverse. The figure wears a decorated collar necklace and a tight-fitting sheath dress with two straps clearly outlined across the shoulders that meet at the breastbone, both traditional artistic items of female clothing and jewellery. The face is broad and fleshy particularly around the jawline, with almond shaped eyes and a short cosmetic line at the outer eye. The lips are thick, and the outer corners are slightly upturned to suggest a subtle smile. On the reverse are the remains of the upper section of the back-pillar, which does not appea… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone statue:  showing the Royal Acquaintance Katep and his wife, the Royal Acquaintance Hetepheres, whose names appear on the statue and also on a false door and other inscribed architectural fragments  from an offering chapel. Katep and Hetepheres sit on a bench with a back that rises to midshoulder height. This arrangement allowed their shoulders and heads to be sculpted entirely in the round. From the front, even the lower torsos, arms, and legs give the illusion of being freed from the stone. While Hetepheres is slightly smaller than her husband, the difference between them is less than one would expect in life. Consequently, she appears almost as Katep's equal, although his is marginally the dominant figure. Katep's torso is well modeled, with the nipples indicated in paint. His shinbones and knees are sharply defined. Hetepheres sits to his right. Her body is set slightly apart from her husband's, but her left arm extends around his back and her hand wraps around his waist. Her slim body is short waisted, and the left breast is smaller and higher than the right, as if to show the backward pull of her arm and shoulder. Her lower legs, her navel, and the lower edge of her rib cage are visible beneath the fabric of her sheath dress, but her nipples are not defined. The nails on the fingers and toes of both figures are care-fully carved and rounded. The faces are similar, with full cheeks, knobby chin, short, slightly upturned nose, and well-defined mouth, which in Katep's case is bordered by a thin painted moustache. The browridges are delicately modeled, and the eyebrows are indicated in black paint. The inner edges of the eyelids are also lined with black and the pupils are painted so that Hetepheres gazes to her right, while Katep looks ahead. Both figures originally wore jewellery, but the blue and green paint that indicated it have vanished almost entirely, except for traces on Hetepheres' anklets. A bracelet on her right wrist is outlined with faint black lines, and a broad collar, now almost indistinguishable from her white dress, is still faintly indicated by concentric light and dark bands. The absence of yellow paint, the colour used for women's skin, around her neck suggests that Hetepheres also wore a choker, or "dog-collar," necklace. The faint black outline of an inverted triangle between the woman's breasts defines the bottom of the broad collar and the inner edges of her dress straps, the outer edges of which are also outlined. Katep's short, curled wig touches his shoulders and back. It also forms a curved frame for his face. The locks of Hetepheres' wig are twisted inward, toward her face, and join in a softly defined part along the crown of her head. Beneath the wig one sees her natural hair, which is also parted in the centre. A hieroglyphic text is incised on the plinth.

description.value: Limestone statue:  showing the Royal Acquaintance Katep and his wife, the Royal Acquaintance Hetepheres, whose names appear on the statue and also on a false door and other inscribed architectural fragments  from an offering chapel. Katep and Hetepheres sit on a bench with a back that rises to midshoulder height. This arrangement allowed their shoulders and heads to be sculpted entirely in the round. From the front, even the lower torsos, arms, and legs give the illusion of being freed from the stone. While Hetepheres is slightly smaller than her husband, the difference between them is less than one would expect in life. Consequently, she appears almost as Katep's equal, although his is marginally the dominant figure. Katep's torso is well modeled, with the nipples indicated in paint. His shinbones and knees are sharply defined. Hetepheres sits to his right. Her body is set slightly apart from her husband's, but her left arm extends around his back and her hand wraps around his waist. Her slim body is short waisted, and the left breast is smaller and higher than the right, as if to show the backward pull of her arm and shoulder. Her lower legs, her navel, and the lower edge of her rib cage are visible beneath the fabric of her sheath dress, but her nipples are not defined. The browridges are delicately modeled, and the eyebrows are indicated in black paint. The inner edges of the eyelids are also lined with black and the pupils are painted so that Hetepheres gazes to her right, while Katep looks ahead. Both figures originally wore jewellery, but the blue and green paint that indicated it have vanished almost entirely, except for traces on Hetepheres' anklets. A bracelet on her right wrist is outlined with faint black lines, and a broad collar, now almost indistinguishable from her white dress, is still faintly indicated by concentric light and dark bands. The absence of yellow paint, the colour used for women's skin, around her neck suggests that Hetepheres also wore a choker, or "dog-collar," necklace. The faint black outline of an inverted triangle between the woman's breasts defines the bottom of the broad collar and the inner edges of her dress straps, the outer edges of which are also outlined. Katep's short, curled wig touches his shoulders and back. It also forms a curved frame for his face. The locks of Hetepheres' wig are twisted inward, toward her face, and join in a softly defined part along the crown of her head. Beneath the wig one sees her natural hair, which is also parted in the centre. A hieroglyphic text is incised on the plinth.

description.value: Limestone block-statue; at the front of the legs is a relief representation of Osiris flanked by incised representations of Isis and Horus; Hieroglyphic text on the plinth.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone block statue of Parenu.

He wears a smooth shoulder-length wig that blends into the top of the block form. His eyes are rounded with a thin incised upper eyelid. His eyebrows are modelled in raised relief. His nose is long and slim while his lips are thick and pursed together. His jawline is rounded. His arms are crossed over the top of the block form. At the front of the block form a figure of Osiris is represented in the round. He wears the atef crown, a false beard, and is shown in mummified form. He holds the crook and flail across his chest. On either side of Osiris, a relief representation of Isis and Horus face towards the god. The sides of the block form are modelled to convey Parenu’s body, with indications of his arm, chest, and the leg. On the reverse is a broad back-pillar inscribed with three columns of text reading from right to left. Each side of the statue base is also inscribed with a continuous line of text.

The edges of the base are broken … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Sandstone statue of Paser: a kneeling figure of the viceroy of Kush, Paser, holding an altar on the top of which rests a ram's head. An inscription incised down the front of the altar consists of an invocation to Amun-Ra resident in Pr-R?mss-mry-‘Imn p? dm?. Prayers to Min and Isis are incised along the base. The back pillar bears two columns of text containing prayers to Horus, lord of Nubia, and Amun-Ra on behalf of the viceroy of Kush, Paser. The back pillar and edges of the base have suffered much wear on the surface. The statue was broken in two when found and has since been repaired. The flesh of the statue is coloured red, the wig black and the gown white with red stripes, but these colours may have been added in modern times. There are traces of blue paint in many of the hieroglyphs.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

There are traces of blue paint in many of the hieroglyphs.

description.value: Sandstone statue of Paser: a kneeling figure of the viceroy of Kush, Paser, holding an altar on the top of which rests a ram's head. An inscription incised down the front of the altar consists of an invocation to Amun-Ra resident in Pr-R?mss-mry-‘Imn p? dm?. Prayers to Min and Isis are incised along the base. The back pillar bears two columns of text containing prayers to Horus, lord of Nubia, and Amun-Ra on behalf of the viceroy of Kush, Paser. The back pillar and edges of the base have suffered much wear on the surface. The statue was broken in two when found and has since been repaired. The flesh of the statue is coloured red, the wig black and the gown white with red stripes, but these colours may have been added in modern times. There are traces of blue paint in many of the hieroglyphs.

description.value: Head from a statue of an aged man.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Quartzite head from a statue of an aged man: the face has soft, sagging flesh and wrinkles. The smile is less pronounced than on those of earlier Twenty-sixth Dynasty statues and when combined with the downward lines of their facial folds and wrinkles, the effect is a curiously ambiguous expression. There is an indication of wrinkles on the upper lids. Within their puffy lids, the eyes have symmetrically curved upper and lower rims with pointed corners. They are smaller and narrower than usual, and slightly slanted. These details are doubtless meant to increase the impression of age.The unmistakably Middle Kingdom form of the wig leaves no doubt that the head belongs to the genre of late archaizing representations of aged men. It may well be the likeness of a specific individual.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Pale quartzite head from the statue of an aged male official, the body and statue base now missing.   The figure wears a flared wig with slight waves which is set low along the forehead and tucked behind the large ears. The face appears fleshy around the nose and mouth area with notable wrinkles around the eyelids and sagging flesh around the chin, and visible downward lines across the mouth area. All of these features, and the soft appearance of the figure’s flesh and slight puffiness of the eyes, convey that the statue represents a mature figure. The symmetrical almond shaped eyes and the thick lower lip curved into a very subtle smile are also traits of Late Period artistic style.  Both sides of the wig are now broken off below the ear, while the figure’s nose and bottom of the chin are also damaged. There are also several chips and abrasions notable at the front of the wig and forehead, the right side of the face and mouth, and at the left ear.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary basalt statue of a royal figure, only the left foot and side of the base remaining.

At the top of the foot are a series of incised lines with one row of patterned detail, likely indicating the hem of his garment or possibly an anklet. The foot is broad in size, with little definition of the ankle. On top of the base is a brief incised inscription containing the name of the goddess Hathor. Around the left side of the base is a partial horizontal line of incised text defined by a thin border and containing royal titles, but no name of a king survives.

There are various small chips to the foot and across the top of the statue base, including a chip to the final hieroglyph sign of the incised text on this surface. The object is now attached to a modern rectangular base.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary basalt figure of the god Osiris, only the upper body remaining.

The god wears a wide broad collar with individual rows of beaded detail, and the outline of his now missing false beard is visible in the centre. His arms were crossed across his chest, as shown by the remains of the heqa-crook on his right side, while across his left side he would have held a flail. A thin part of the flail is still intact across this area, though most of this is now badly damaged and his hands are also lost. The intact right side of the upper body also confirms that the god adopted his traditional mummified form, with the outline of the elbow underneath the material still visible. On the reverse is a section of a slim back-pillar, now badly damaged and with no clear traces of an inscription.

In addition to the loss of the head, lower body, and back-pillar, the left side of the body has been reconstructed in modern times.

description.value: Feet and base from a fragmentary green steatite statue, the head and upper body of the figure now missing.  The feet and part of the lower legs of the figure appear to be enveloped in a cloak, suggesting that the full body was likely covered or depicted in mummified form. The stone fill between the feet and the surviving section of the back-pillar suggests that the figure was perhaps originally depicted in a seated pose. The intact lower section of the back-pillar on the reverse includes the conclusion of a crudely carved inscription, the upper portion now lost. Across the top of the statue base in front of the figure’s feet are five horizontal lines of text reading from right to left. Around the edges of the statue base are incised decorative friezes, with three cartouches presented at the front of the statue base bearing royal names.  There are small chips around the edges of the statue base, particularly at the front right corner and towards the reverse. There are also small scratch… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Fragmentary granite figure of a king, now headless and with much of the body and base now missing.  The king is depicted wearing the nemes headcloth, with long lappets which extend down onto the chest. The chest is bare, with broad arms and a notable narrowing at the waist.  There is a slight indication of a bend at the left arm, which may indicate that this was a seated statue. Much of the reverse has been damaged and little now remains, however based on the width of the stone intact at the back of the king’s figure it is likely that there was a high backed chair or a back-pillar on the reverse.   In addition to the loss of the lower body from the torso and the loss of the king’s head, there are numerous chips across the statue surface. There are also further cracks at the neck area in between the nemes lappets.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary white quartz seated figure of a king, the upper body now lost.

The figure sits on a smooth block throne and wears a short shendyt kilt, with both hands placed across the thighs. The broad lower legs are positioned close together and the feet are carefully rendered. Across the top of the base just in front of the right foot is a very slim surviving section of incised text with an epithet referencing the god Sobek.

The throne is heavily damaged on the left side at both corners and extending onto the base at both the front and back. There are chips to the body across the right side kilt and left hand and forearm.

description.value:
Limestone seated statue of the male official Nedjem.

He wears a shoulder-length double wig with an undersection of tighter curls below his ears. Black paint has been applied to the wig, eyes, and eyebrows, and red-brown paint has been used to denote his skin. His eyebrows are thin and modelled in raised relief, and slope sharply down to the temple. His eyes are almond shaped with elongated cosmetic lines at the outer corners. His nose is slim and pointed, and his mouth is small with thick lips which are pursed together. His face is particularly rounded and fleshy around the mouth and jawline area. His upper body is bare, and both hands rest on his lap. In his left hand he holds a piece of folded cloth. He wears a long kilt belted at the waist, with a knotted loop of material at the right side of his torso. White paint has been used for his clothing. A single column of text is inscribed along the centre of his garment. Traces of red paint are visible in the borders, and a dark … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Part of a granite statue: the lower half of a seated figure of a man, carved in black granite and carefully polished. The figure wears a short kilt and is seated on a stool with hollowed sides of the usual Early Dynastic type. The right hand rests on the lap; the feet were originally shown close together although the right foot is now missing. There is a raised ridge running up the outside of the legs from the ankle to just below the knee, to indicate the musculature. On the surviving foot, the toenails are shown. The figure was made in one piece with a low pedestal, the edges of which are considerably broken. On the upper surface of the pedestal, beside the broken right foot, was an inscription consisting of a vertical line of hieroglyphs. The majority of the surviving hieroglyphs are on a piece of the base which has been entirely broken off and replaced out of its true position, causing a slight shift in the location of the head of the m-sign, a hieroglyph resembling an owl, at the top, in relation to the rest of the sign.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary grey granite seated statue of a male figure, part of the lower body and backless seat now remaining.

The figure wears a short knee-length kilt with a curved incised line across his knees indicating the edge of the material. The partially intact right forearm is placed flat across the lap. His legs are broad and placed close together, with the musculature indicated via a thin raised ridge along the front of his calves. His left foot is also broad in size, and has delineated toenails. His right foot is now lost. Each side of the seat has a hollowed out section decorated with an inverted semi-circular shape in the centre. On top of the base at the missing right foot is a partial incised inscription that is now placed closer to the edge due to the loss of the original base.

Part of the right arm, upper leg, and a large section of the statue base have been reconstructed in modern times. The right side foot has large chips to the ankle area, and another chip is… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Granodiorite seated statue of Sekhmet. The sides of the throne are decorated with the motif of binding the plants of the Two Lands and the throne is also inscribed on the front edges with the names of Amenhotep 3. The left hand holds an ankh-sign; the right is much restored. The front of the plinth and the feet is all restoration, as is each side of the solar disk headdress. There is a join with some restoration at the base of the collar. Pink crystals are evident in the grey granite of the face.

description.value: Forepart of head of a gypsum statue; resembling Caesar.  A plaster portrait head, probably of Julius Caesar, with the hair brushed forward around the ears, and receding considerably above the forehead. The brow is furrowed, the nose is damaged, and ridges run from the nose, round the mouth, to the chin. The pupils of the eyes are marked, the gaze upwards. A small area of drapery shows on the left side of the neck. The rear of the head is hollow behind the face, and casting webs run across the top of the head and down each side. A cleaned-up casting web runs down the centre line of the face: what survives of this object was made in a multipiece mould.  White plaster. The hollow at the back is now filled with modern plaster used to mount the object on its stand.

description.value:
Fragmentary brown stone naophorous male figure, part of the upper body and top of the naos remaining.

The body has a clean break at the neck, and the musculature of the bare chest and collarbone area is faintly modelled. There is a clear narrowing of his waist on both the front and reverse. Both upper arms are held close to the side of the body. At his chest is the intact upper section of a slim naos, which appears to have a sloping surface along the top. On the reverse is a surviving portion of a broad back-pillar, incised with a slim column of text which is defined by a border. The upper and lower portion of this back-pillar is now lost.

The front corners of the naos are both damaged, and there are chips along the edge of the back-pillar and lower right side of the body. The object is attached to a modern base that partly reconstructs the shape of the naos and lower body.

description.value:
Limestone head of a male figure.

He wears a straight wig that is broken off at the edges, but likely reached to his shoulders. The wig is tucked behind his ears, which are slightly oversized. There are faint traces of a darker colour visible across some sections of the wig, suggesting it may once have been painted. Across the face are clear traces of red paint, the conventional colour used to portray male skin. His eyes are rounded with a heavy upper eyelid and elongated cosmetic lines at the outer edges. His eyebrows are slim and extend down towards the temple. He has an aquiline nose with a broad tip, and his lips are fleshy with the outer corners upturned slightly, forming a small smile.

The left side of the wig has been particularly damaged by a number of larger gouges, with smaller abrasions visible around the edges of the wig along the reverse and right side. description.value:
Fragmentary basalt block statue of a male official.

The top of the block form is damaged, though traces of his arms are notable suggesting that his arms are folded and his left hand is placed flat across the surface. His body is fully enveloped, with subtle bulging at both sides to indicate his legs. Across the front of the block form are four horizontal lines of inscription, the final line partly obscured. Along the reverse and right side of the base are remains of a continuous horizontal line of incised text, the rest now missing.

The top of the block form is heavily damaged, and the feet and front of the statue base have also broken away. There are various chips to the stone surface across the block form, and across the base. The statue is now placed on a modern mount.

description.value:
Fragmentary brown diorite(?) male figure, the lower body now lost.

The figure wears a smooth shoulder-length wig. His facial features are mostly obscured, though his eyes appear almond shaped with a visible cosmetic line at the outer corners. There is a thick line and the suggestion of sunken skin underneath the right eye. The remaining outline of his eyebrows suggests that they were slightly arched. The nose and mouth are no longer clearly delineated, and the face is fleshy and rounded at the jawline. His upper body is bare, with clear modelling of the chest and abdomen. Both arms are held by the side of the body and his waist is narrowed. On the reverse is a slim back-pillar that reaches to the ends of his wig. A slim column of incised text is defined by a border, with the lower portion of the back-pillar now lost.

In addition to the break at the waist, there are small chips to the stone surface across the wig and body. There are further chips around the face. The o… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Head of a black basalt male figure.

He wears a striated wig that sits low on the forehead, and the ends of the wig are now damaged. His eyebrows are thin and modelled in raised relief, and slope sharply down his brow. His eyes are sharply incised with a short cosmetic line emerging from the outer corners. His nose is damaged at the tip but broad in size at the nostrils. There is only a narrow space between his nose and upper lip. His lips are thick and pursed together, with the outer corners of the mouth flat. There is a large gouge to the stone at his chin and neck, and at either side of the upper body. On the reverse is the top section of a slim back-pillar.

There are several large cracks across the reverse that extend over the top of the head and down onto the face. Other small cracks are visible across the cheeks. The head is now mounted onto a slim base.
