legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone head of a king, a sculptor’s model or trial piece.

The king wears the nemes headcloth, with a uraeus ornament representing the coiled body of a cobra placed at the centre, its head now missing. His eyes are narrow with thin incised lines indicating the upper eyelids, and thin strips in raised relief indicating the eyebrows. His nose has broken off, but its outline on the right side is preserved. The lips are curved into a gentle smile. The face is round and fleshy, particularly around the mouth and jaw. The reverse is a flat surface that appears to be undecorated, with a modern label in faded black ink of ‘Benha 1871’.

In addition to numerous breaks around the nemes cloth, uraeus and the nose, there are various small chips across the face and neck. The object is now attached to a modern rectangular base.

The king wears the nemes headcloth, with a uraeus ornament representing the coiled body of a cobra placed at the centre, its head now missing. His eyes are narrow with thin incised lines indicating the upper eyelids, and thin strips in raised relief indicating the eyebrows. His nose has broken off, but its outline on the right side is preserved. The lips are curved into a gentle smile. The face is round and fleshy, particularly around the mouth and jaw. The reverse is a flat surface that appears to be undecorated, with a modern label in faded black ink of ‘Benha 1871’.

In addition to numerous breaks around the nemes cloth, uraeus and the nose, there are various small chips across the face and neck. The object is now attached to a modern rectangular base.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Red granite lion statue: the prenomen and nomen of Ramses II with the epithet 'beloved like Horus' are incised on the back of this recumbent lion. An incised inscription, originally written twice around the base, gives the Horus name, 'nebty' name, prenomen and nomen of Ramses II with the same epithet. This statue has suffered badly from damp and erosion. The entire front of the lion has been worn away leaving only the back in a good state of preservation. The lower left side of the base on the back has been slightly chipped with loss to the inscription probably during transport from Athribis.

description.value: Kneeling mudstone figure of Ramses IV.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Mudstone statue of Ramses IV: a kneeling figure of Ramses IV wearing the 'nemes' head-dress and 'shendyt' kilt. On his right shoulder is incised his prenomen, and his nomen is carved on his left shoulder. His prenomen is also incised in an oval in the centre of the girdle of his kilt. The back pillar bears two columns of incised hieroglyphs giving the king's names with epithets. Fragments of the king's name and titles remain on the right and left sides of the base. At the top of the base there are the remains of inscriptions on the right and left sides. The front part of the statue including the front of the base, knees and hands of the figure are lost and have been restored in recent times with a 'nw'-bowl in each hand. The rear of the base and the bottom of the back pillar have also been lost and recently restored. The nose and uraeus of the figure have been damaged. The surviving portion of the back pillar is worn in places. There are no traces of colour.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Bronze upper part of a standing man: with the remains of a sand quartz core. This fragmentary statue of a standing man wears a type of wig that was especially popular during the Twenty-first and Twenty-second Dynasties, and a modified version of the New Kingdom tunic, with less floppy sleeves. There seems to be no indication of the kilt or sash that one would expect with this garment. The man's bland, handsome face, a blend of several New Kingdom styles, resembles representations of Osorkon II and other figures of the Twenty-second Dynasty. Traces of gold show that it was at least partly gilded. The man's wig is quite clearly a separate piece. The chest is incised with a depiction of three seated deities  upon a 'nb'-basket.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: COMPASS Title: Limestone statue of Panehsy

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Naophorous limestone figure of Panehesy: a kneeling statue of the overseer of the treasury, Panehesy, who holds between his hands a naos containing the figures of Horus, Osiris and Isis and surmounted by a winged sun-disk. The prenomen of Ramses II is incised on the right shoulder of the statue, and his nomen appears on the left shoulder. Along the front edges of the naos are incised two prayers on behalf of Panehesy. On the lap of the figure are carved two horizontal lines of text which name Ramses II and Panehesy, son of Ramose, and below these on the top of the shrine are five columns of text with invocations to Osiris, Isis, Horus, Wepwawet and Anubis. These prayers continue on the right side of the naos in one horizontal and three vertical lines and on the left side of the naos in a similar fashion. A line of text containing two prayers runs along the base. Two columns of text are also incised down the back pillar. The statue has suffered much surface damage with resultant cracks and flaking. The bottom of the base has been lost, and parts of the top and sides of the naos and the front of the base were lost prior to its acquisition. A small fragment from the front of the naos and the rear two corners of the base appear to have been lost since its acquisition. There are no traces of colour.

description.value: Face from a black granite statue of a king; front of the nemes and uraeus visible.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Fragmentary black granite royal head.  The king wears the nemes headcloth with well-preserved traces of gold colour, and the cloth area is delineated with rough and smooth ridges to create the vertical striped pattern. The nemes is broken at both sides above the ear, but originally would have had lappets which folded down at either side of the face and extended down to the chest. Across the centre of the nemes is the coiled body of the uraeus cobra, the fragmentary head and raised hood positioned above the king's forehead. A horizontal band is incised along the outer edge of the nemes and set low on the forehead. His eyes are almond shaped with visible elongated cosmetic lines at the outer edges. His eyebrows are thin and arched. His face is fleshy with slightly sunken skin underneath the eyes and rounded cheeks. His mouth is small in size but with thick lips that form a small smile. The stone has been chipped away at both sides resulting in a loss of the king's ears, and on the revers… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Head from a black granite group statue.

The male figure wears a double wig with a tight underlayer of curls. This wig partially covers his ears, and is set low on the forehead. His eyebrows are modelled in raised relief, and his eyes are almond shaped with a thin incised line for his upper eyelid. At the outer corners of his eyes is a short cosmetic line. His nose is damaged, though the outline of the slim bridge of his nose is still visible. His mouth is also damaged, but the outer corners are still intact. His lips appear thick and pursed together. There are further gouges to the face around the chin, but the jawline is rounded and fleshy. The head is broken at the edges of his wig. On the reverse, below the left edge of his wig are hieroglyph signs that suggest he had text inscribed across his body. There is also the left side portion of a broad back-pillar or high-backed seat, which is inscribed with eight columns of incised text. The right edge of this is damaged, obscuri… (See Merlin record for full description)
